Which plan's better, Obama's or McCain's?
I don't think either one of them have a plan yet that comes close to putting us on a more prudent fiscal path.
In the case of Senator Obama, he's talking about a lot of additional spending.
In the case of Senator McCain, he's talking about additional tax cuts.

Neither one of them plans to add up right now, but it's still fairly early, and I'm hoping that fiscal responsibility and intergenerational equity will become a major issue in the general-election campaign.

Families of those killed will be awarded $180,000 each.
Those injured are eligible for 40 to $90,000, depending on how long they spent in the hospital, plus free tuition at Virginia Tech.
Students who were on the second floor of Norris Hall, the day of the shooting but not injured, will receive $10,000 or free tuition.
It was up to Kenneth Feinberg to come up with the formula for how those funds would be divided.

9/11: unlimited budget, all public money.
Virginia Tech: very limited budget, all private money.
9/11: I had to calculate by statute a different amount for every claimant.
Hokie Spirit Memorial Fund: all the families of the dead get the same, all those hospitalized for a certain degree of time get the same, all those traumatized get the same.
9/11 fund: you had to waive your right to litigate against the airlines, the World Trade Center, the port authority.
The Virginia Tech plan has no preconditions whatsoever.
Basically, it's a gift.
The plan for what you would - how you would distribute the money evolved some over the time that you've been working on it.

Well, the very first thing I heard was, Mr. Feinberg, please give every family a choice.

Some may want to take the money and divide it up - some scholarship, some cash.
Some may want to take the money and do what they will.
Secondly, was this uniformed view that the fund should not be shut down prematurely, that the Hokie Spirit Memorial Fund may yet receive additional funds.
And therefore, will you please extend the life of the fund as far out as possible.

We want an audit.

Virginia Tech, I believe, thinks it is taxable.
They will issue a 1099 with each of the checks that go to eligible families.
I've also heard, however, that like 9/11, which was not taxable, an argument - a strong argument can be made that it is not taxable.
So in the protocol, I suggest that every recipient consult with their own tax lawyer, their own accountant and make that decision for themselves.
That seems like a pretty basic question that families would want answered before they took the money.

When you talk to the Virginia Tech families, is there still a great deal of residual anger?

Now, it's a little different, as I say, from 9/11 where you had to waive your right to sue.

Just as the 9/11 fund, by statute, expired.
So, too, here, we should have all the funds in by the end of the year, and they'll be distributed.

For generations, golfers have gotten goosebumps as they drive down Magnolia Lane, under the canopy of southern magnolias framing the Augusta National Golf Club.
Farther north the deciduous magnolias are now in flower.
In some parts of the country, these magnolias are even past their prime, their petals stomped into a sticky brown pulp on the sidewalk.
But the fate of many of the world's wild magnolias is far, far worse.
They may never see spring again.
We tell their story this week on Science Out of The Box.
(Soundbite of music)
Empty forests.
That's what researchers found when they looked for wild magnolias around the globe - from Asia, where about two-thirds of wild magnolias live, to the United States and as far south as Colombia.
Sara Oldfield is secretary general of Botanic Gardens Conservation International and one of the authors of a study published this week by two British conservation groups.
Well, we contacted expert in all the countries where magnolias occur in the wild and found that over half of all the species of magnolias in the wild are threatened with extinction.
That's 131 of the world's 245 known wild species in danger.
Mostly, Oldfield says, because of deforestation.
The researchers compared maps of magnolia trees with satellite maps of the forests they live in.
They found, not surprisingly, that as forests were cut back magnolias were cut back too.
For example, in Colombia, one species, magnolia wolfii, is reduced to less than 10 individuals and that's the consequence of coffee plantations taking over the national habitat of that species.
But Richard Figlar, scientific advisor of the International Magnolia Society, says wild magnolias themselves are partly responsible for their predicament.
They are gap colonizers.
That is a tend to seed themselves in little disturbances in the forests, sometimes called gaps.
So as a result, all 240 or so species of magnolias is relatively uncommon where they grow, or in fact I can say mostly rare.
Wipe out just one little pocket of magnolias and the whole species is gone, just as of all the finches died on an island in the Galapagos.
So about that species in Colombia where only 10 trees are left?
Not surprising, Figlar says.
In fact in Colombia, all 30 species are endangered species in remote mountain areas.
It was a kind of gamble that magnolias took millions of years ago, heading for the hills.
That debt, though, paid of for a really long time.
The earliest magnolia fossils are known to be about 75 to 85 million years old.
They would have seen the end of the dinosaurs, for example.
Perhaps dinosaurs munched on these trees at one time.
They've survived continental drift, mountain formation, even ice ages.
But there is not much a magnolia tree can do about a chainsaw.
So Sara Oldfield and her colleagues are trying to store away samples of the threatened magnolias in botanical gardens across the world, hoping for a time when they can be replanted in the wild.
